docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organisation advised women on Wednesday on how to protect themselves from Zika, particularly if pregnant, but also reassured them that most women in areas affected by the mosquito-borne virus will give birth to "normal infants."

headline.main: WHO Advises Women on Zika Protection but No Travel Advisories
headline.print_headline: WHO Advises Women on Zika Protection but No Travel Advisories

docs.snippet: The World Health Organisation advised women on Wednesday on how to protect themselves from Zika, particularly if pregnant, but also reassured them that most women in areas affected by the mosquito-borne virus will give birth to "normal infants."

docs.lead_paragraph: The Zika virus might cause eye damage in small-headed infants born to women infected during pregnancy, a small study in Brazil suggests.

headline.main: Babies' Eye Damage and Zika? Brazil Study Suggests a Link
headline.print_headline: Babies' Eye Damage and Zika? Brazil Study Suggests a Link

docs.snippet: The Zika virus might cause eye damage in small-headed infants born to women infected during pregnancy, a small study in Brazil suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Wednesday advised women in areas with the Zika virus, especially during pregnancy, to cover  up against mosquitoes and practice safe sex but also reassured them that most would give birth to "normal infants".

headline.main: WHO Urges Precautions in Zika Areas but Reassures Most Births Normal
headline.print_headline: WHO Urges Precautions in Zika Areas but Reassures Most Births Normal

docs.snippet: The World Health Organization on Wednesday advised women in areas with the Zika virus, especially during pregnancy, to cover  up against mosquitoes and practice safe sex but also reassured them that most would give birth to "normal infants".

docs.lead_paragraph: A Roman Catholic group appealed to Pope Francis on Wednesday to allow Church members to "follow their conscience" and use contraception or to let women have abortions to protect themselves against the Zika virus.

headline.main: Catholic Group Urges Pope to Allow Contraception to Fight Zika
headline.print_headline: Catholic Group Urges Pope to Allow Contraception to Fight Zika

docs.snippet: A Roman Catholic group appealed to Pope Francis on Wednesday to allow Church members to "follow their conscience" and use contraception or to let women have abortions to protect themselves against the Zika virus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Portugal's parliament on Wednesday overturned the presidential veto on a bill legalising adoption by same-sex couples, which means conservative President Anibal Cavaco Silva will have to sign it into law before his term ends in March.

headline.main: Portugal Parliament Overturns Veto on Adoption by Gay Couples
headline.print_headline: Portugal Parliament Overturns Veto on Adoption by Gay Couples

docs.snippet: Portugal's parliament on Wednesday overturned the presidential veto on a bill legalising adoption by same-sex couples, which means conservative President Anibal Cavaco Silva will have to sign it into law before his term ends in March.

headline.main: To Reduce the Risk of Alzheimer’s, Eat Fish

docs.abstract: Among carriers of the gene that increases Alzheimer’s risk, a study found a benefit from eating seafood at least once a week.
docs.snippet: Among carriers of the gene that increases Alzheimer’s risk, a study found a benefit from eating seafood at least once a week.

docs.lead_paragraph: Six months pregnant with her first child, Eritania Maria has a rash and a mild fever, symptoms of the Zika virus linked to brain deformities in newborn children in Brazil.

headline.main: Zika, Disease of the Poor, May Not Change Abortion in Brazil
headline.print_headline: Zika, Disease of the Poor, May Not Change Abortion in Brazil

docs.snippet: Six months pregnant with her first child, Eritania Maria has a rash and a mild fever, symptoms of the Zika virus linked to brain deformities in newborn children in Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of 29 newborns at a hospital in Salvador, Brazil, found that 10 had defects in the retina or optic nerve of one or both eyes.

headline.main: Study in Brazil Links Zika Virus to Eye Damage in Babies
headline.print_headline: Study in Brazil Links Zika Virus to Eye Damage in Babies

docs.abstract: Study published in JAMA Ophthalmology finds that infants infected with Zika virus may be born with eye abnormalities as well as unusually small heads.
docs.snippet: A study of 29 newborns at a hospital in Salvador, Brazil, found that 10 had defects in the retina or optic nerve of one or both eyes.

byline.contributor: Jane Perlez contributed reporting from Beijing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Experts from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are heading to Puerto Rico this week to study whether the mosquito-borne Zika virus will cause an increase in cases of a rare neurological disorder known as Guillain-Barre syndrome as the outbreak intensifies in this U.S. territory.

headline.main: U.S. to Study Zika Link to Guillain-Barre in Puerto Rico
headline.print_headline: U.S. to Study Zika Link to Guillain-Barre in Puerto Rico

docs.snippet: Experts from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are heading to Puerto Rico this week to study whether the mosquito-borne Zika virus will cause an increase in cases of a rare neurological disorder known as Guillain-Barre syndrome as...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has no immediate need for funding to combat the Zika virus because money remains unspent from fighting the two-year-long Ebola outbreak, a member of the Republican Senate leadership said on Tuesday.

headline.main: Republican Senator: Obama Administration Already Has Funds for Zika
headline.print_headline: Republican Senator: Obama Administration Already Has Funds for Zika

docs.snippet: The Obama administration has no immediate need for funding to combat the Zika virus because money remains unspent from fighting the two-year-long Ebola outbreak, a member of the Republican Senate leadership said on Tuesday.
